text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today 
I'm making what is essentially a vegetarian Pad

Thai but the inspiration came from a dish called 
Pat mee korat korat is a town in the northeast of

Thailand where my mom and my grandmother are 
from and so this dish is the local specialty

to korat and it happens to be very similar 
to pad thai in both flavor and ingredients but

my grandmother's recipe happens to be vegetarian 
so here's a treat for all my vegetarian fans out

there let's get started alright new dough so 
I'm using dry rice noodles widely available

everywhere the size that I like is about two to 
three millimeters wide some brands will call that

medium some brands will call that small this one 
calls it medium so you're just going to have to

look I soak this in room-temperature water for an 
hour and then take it out and it will look like

that it's pliable it's white if you want to soak 
the noodles in advance you can do that and then

take them out of the water put them in a ziploc 
bag and then keep it in the fridge until you're

ready to cook I'm going to mix the sauce in One 
Bowl ahead of time okay so the main ingredient

for this sauce is actually about deal or fermented 
soybean paste now I've used this in a few of my

videos and it's basically soy beans that have 
been fermented if you cannot find this you can

also use miso paste okay you need a little bit 
less but I'll give all that in my written recipe

and this is actually an iconic ingredient for 
Pat Miko at and it's a great substitute for fish

sauce because it's got that sharp acidity lots of 
umami I like to mash them up so that it's better

distributed amongst the noodles so now that that's 
all a mush I'm going to go in with some soy sauce

tamarind juice this is going to have a note of 
acidity that's quite prominent and just so you

can see what the package looks like it doesn't 
have to be this brand I don't always use this

brand I use basically or whatever is available 
and it should say it's hammerin concentrate on

it okay and then some water going in optional 
some chili flakes I like to make this a a bit

spicy but you don't have to and that's it that's 
the sauce just going to quickly go through the

other ingredients in this recipe so I've got 
some shiitake mushrooms some fresh ones which

look like that and I take all the stems out and I 
cut them into thin slices like this it's a great

meat substitute for really any dish so I love 
shitake mushrooms usual duo in pop K which is

bean sprouts and garlic chives they bean sprout 
you can get them in any Asian grocery store garlic

chives they come whole like that and if you can't 
find these you can either use green onions or you

can use regular chives the goal here is to get 
something oniony garlicky in it lastly i'm using

pressed tofu the same kind of use in my peptide 
video and it's got a firm texture like cheese

it's very firm so it's great for stir frying 
it's not going to break you just want little

pieces just like that and these are optional you 
don't need to put in tofu if you don't want to the

other ingredients that I have is some chopped 
garlic and shallots and also some chopped palm

sugar that is it we are ready to go cook so I'm 
going to start by cooking off the mushrooms and

the tofu just sear them off a little bit 
so that they get a little caramelization

by the way if you're not vegetarian and you want 
to add me instead of mushrooms and sofu you can

do that as well I would also pre cook the meat 
here give it a little time to sear don't stir

them just yet get a flip and don't add too 
much oil at this stage because the mushrooms

absorb a lot of oil so if you give it a lot 
it will pick up a lot all right good enough

for me I just wanted some golden brown some 
searing add a little more oil this time you

want to be generous because if you don't add 
enough oil and you'll want to keep it lean

your noodles are going to get sticky and clump 
up that's one of the things that a lot of people

go wrong is they don't have an add enough oil 
and the rice noodles are clumpy and they don't

understand why so in here I'm going to add my 
palm sugar and also some garlic and shallots

so I'm going to hook the palm sugar until it 
becomes caramelized and dark and that's how

we're going to develop flavor and also color so 
the sugar will slowly melt and then it'll start

to turn a dark amber color so you can imagine 
how good palm sugar is and how good caramelized

palm sugar is mm-hmm all right that looks good 
it's dark brown I am going in with the sauce ooh

and it will bubble aggressively and then I'm 
going to go in with the noodles that of soaks

and also the mushrooms and the tofu that we cooked 
earlier I'm going to change weapon because now I

need to twist and toss and you're going to do 
this until all the sauces absorb keep an eye

on it if it looks like it needs more liquid you 
can add extra water okay because the amount of

liquid that evaporates when you add the sauce will 
differ from pan Japan from how hot your pan was I

think this definitely needs a little more water 
and that just takes experience as well the first

time just cook until everything's absorbed give 
the noodles a taste and if it's still too chewy

add a little more water let it cook a little bit 
more and remember it's better to at too little

water and then having to add more than to that too 
much water in which case it's done at this point

if you want to add eggs you can go ahead and add 
eggs right now but I'm keeping this vegan so I'm

gonna skip that okay that looks pretty good to 
me turn off the heat and add my vegetables and

yes that looks like a lot of vegetables but trust 
me you want a lot of vegetables to lighten up the

noodles otherwise it's going to be really heavy 
it'll look like a lot less when it's done there

you go oh my gosh it's so easy it's done so if 
this is your first time go ahead and taste it

okay and if you want to adjust the seasoning now's 
the time to do that here we go see if you all the

noodles enough they will separate nicely rather 
than clump up together now it's not the time to

be healthy you salad after so pat mccrory at is 
typically a very rustic dish so there's no garnish

or anything like that but and it does it doesn't 
usually come with peanuts but to give it you know

the the air of pad thai i'm going to go ahead 
and add some peanuts anyway because i think it

adds nice crunchiness to it now I don't think this 
needs any more line this recipe doesn't need lime

juice away Pad Thai normally does and pat mckerrod 
doesn't usually come with lime but if you love

fresh lime go ahead and put a little squeeze 
on top if you want and I am perfectly happy

with this one listen regardless of whether you're 
vegetarian or not you need to try this the perfect

balance of sweet salty and sour the noodles chewy 
the mushrooms give that kick of umami flavor it is

so good so you've got vegetarian friends this 
they will love you for it so the recipe is on

hot Thai Kitchen calm when you make it send me a 
photo Facebook Twitter or Instagram and I will see

you next time for your next two dishes tae-bo so 
at decaf welcome to hot Thai Kitchen I'm making
so what Vika what
